segments.text: It is time for another chapter from The Nature of Code.
Now, I've got a little bit of an issue here,
because I'm not entirely sure whether this should be chapter
5 or chapter 6.
In the first edition of the book,
it was distinctly chapter 6, as you're seeing right here,
burned into the screen of this video forever.
But I am toying with the idea of moving this up to chapter 5.
This is not the most important thing
for me to cover in this video.
The important thing is the topic, autonomous agents.
And this is why I am so gosh darn excited about this topic.
Let's say I have a table.
And I were to place a block on the edge of that table.
Adding a wind force, expressed as a vector,
this block, this inanimate object with no agency or being
or life or hopes or dreams or fears,
would just blow off and fall off the table.
But what if this wasn't a block?
What if this was a magical creature?
And instead of a gust of wind, there
was a big, bad, scary monster?
And remember, this is no longer an inanimate object.
It's a being with desires and feelings.
And it feels fear.
And it decides on its own with its brain
to leap off of this table to escape from the monster.
Now, I might seem ridiculous going on and on about this.
But this is a big conceptual leap.
An inanimate object, which is all of the simulations
that I've looked at in chapters 1, 2, 3, and 4,
versus an animate object, an object that
has its own ability to perceive its environment,
make decisions, and perform actions
based on those decisions, based on its perception
of the environment.
And this is exactly the way that I
think about what it means to be an autonomous agent
in the context of the examples that I've demonstrated to you
in The Nature of Code book.
So let's, for a moment, zoom all the way
to the end of this chapter.
The last example is a flocking system,
which I'm showing you behind me right now.
Here, I think we can take a peek into what
are the three key components of what it means
to be an autonomous agent.
Number one, an autonomous agent has a limited ability
to perceive its environment.
So it has some kind of sensors built into it.
It knows where it is in relation to other things in the P5 canvas
itself, because that's what we're working with.
But that word limited is really critical.
It's not an all-knowing creature that
can see everything around it.
But we're going to get more unique and lifelike behaviors
if it could only see within a certain distance,
or what's right in front of it.
Or maybe we think about its perception not as vision,
but as some other type of sense-based perception.
An autonomous agent processes the information
from its environment and calculates an action.
Again, this is the critical conceptual leap forward.
Instead of being an inanimate object that's just responding
to forces in the system, the object itself, the agent,
is perceiving and then translating its perception
into a force, into an action that it's going to take.
An autonomous agent has no leader.
Now, this is not necessarily a hard and fast rule
in what you should always do when you're
programming things in P5.js.
But it is an important critical note here
in terms of this flocking example.
This is an example of a complex system, a system that is
more than the sum of its parts.
It exhibits a kind of global intelligence.
And yet, that global intelligence
does not come from a single leader.
There's no one leading the flock around.
The behavior, the emergent behavior that you're seeing,
comes from all of the small local interactions
between all these little triangles
moving around the canvas.
Each one of these what are actually called voids
just follows three simple rules, alignment, cohesion,
separation.
I'm going to get to those rules in a later video
where I go through this in detail.
They're easy to understand and easy to define.
The outcome, the resulting system,
is chaotic and hard to predict.
But I'm getting ahead of myself and veering,
or should I say steering off into strange directions
that I don't need to go down right now.
Because I want to double back and start
with what is the core foundational element of what
it means to be an autonomous agent,
and how does that element link back to everything
I've done already in chapters 1, 2, 3, and 4, and maybe 5.
I'm not really sure.
We can trace everything I'm talking about right now,
all of these ideas, back to the book Vehicles, Experiments
in Synthetic Psychology by Italian neuroscientist
Valentino Breitenberg.
One way of looking at this book is
an exercise in science fiction.
A Breitenberg vehicle is an entity,
a vehicle that is a hypothetical self-operating
machine that can make decisions about how
to behave in an environment based on its sense perception.
Take this example of these two Breitenberg vehicles.
The one on the left, A, has sensors
to detect a light source and always steers away
from that light source, while the one on the right, B,
always steers towards that light source.
But the sort of magic, the wonder of Breitenberg's book
is not the sense of these vehicles
as just steering away or towards,
but as exhibiting emotion through their sense perception
and motion itself.
The left exhibits fear moving away from the light.
The right exhibits aggression moving towards the light.
Breitenberg vehicles have been a source of inspiration
for many artists, notably one of the creators of Processing
itself, Casey Reiss, used them as inspiration
for his series Process Compendium.
Here's also a sketch that simulates Breitenberg vehicles
in Processing itself that Casey Reiss created
as part of his artistic process in developing the series.
I'm really saying the word processing a lot.
Have you noticed that?
So why am I going on and on about this book
called Vehicles?
Well, in addition to just being a wonderful thing on its own,
it serves as a core piece of inspiration
for this paper by Craig Reynolds from the 1999 Game Developers
Conference, Steering Behaviors for Autonomous Characters.
And in this paper, Reynolds proposes a set
of solutions for autonomous characters
to behave in a world in a lifelike and improvisational
manner.
This work is key and fundamental to so much
that we experience in today's computer graphics, animation,
games, films, interactive systems, all of that stuff.
And ultimately, what I want to do in this chapter
is outline the core principles of Reynolds' paper
and implement, re-implement those principles using P5.js
and all of the stuff that I've done in chapters 1, 2, 3, 4,
et cetera.
In fact, scrolling down in the paper itself,
under a simple vehicle model, we quickly
find that what are the properties of that vehicle?
Mass, position, velocity, max force, max speed, orientation.
This is exactly everything that I've
done with mover, a particle, and now
what I'm going to call vehicle.
In the paper, Reynolds takes the idea
of the motion of an autonomous character
and divides it into three steps.
So I'm going to go through a little bit about these three
steps, but I want you to just get out your mental notepad
and take a note of this first one.
Action selection.
This is really where your own creativity can shine.
What are the agents, the characters in your world,
what are their goals?
What are their hopes and dreams and fears?
What's their strategy?
What kind of plans do they have?
This is really, I'm going to go through some canonical
examples of steering behaviors like seeking a target,
fleeing a target, but you are going
to have your own creative ideas of what kind of world
you want to build.
Steering, this is going to be the big focus
of the next video.
It's actually a very simple formula,
and it all boils down to calculating a force.
So we're really lucky we spent two whole chapters going on
about vectors and forces because it's going to boil down
to a formula to calculate a steering force.
And then locomotion is how does that agent, that character,
how does it animate, how does it move?
So in one sense, that's the physics engine you're using.
And in our case, it's position, velocity, acceleration,
or maybe you're using a different physics engine.
But also, you can think about what is its design?
Does it have oscillating wings?
Lots of other things that you could put also
your creative spin on.
If you have the time, I really would recommend
reading the full paper.
It's pretty accessible and explains
all the different kinds of concepts and actual algorithms
for the different steering behaviors in a lot of detail.
Ultimately, it's my goal, personal goal,
to have a p5.js example for every one of these behaviors
that Craig Reynolds outlines.
I have a bunch of them already, and I'm
going to do some of them in videos,
and then maybe eventually on the Nature of Code website
or in the Coding Train website, you'll
be able to find additional ones.
But if you want to contribute and try any of them
that I haven't done already, I highly encourage you to do so.
I should also note here this distinction
between simple behaviors for individuals and pairs
and combined behaviors in groups.
So this idea of emergence of a complex system,
that's really going to arrive when
I get to going through combined group behaviors,
flocking being the one that I refer to as the sort
of ultimate example of this chapter.
But I'm going to start in a few videos
just going through the sort of core foundational examples
of what it means to program an implementation of Craig
Reynolds' steering force.
And the first one I'm going to start with is just seeking
and fleeing a target.
And that's what will be in the next video.
I really hope that these concepts inspire you
and that you discover a new set of tools or ideas
that you can incorporate into your own practice,
whatever that may be.
And I can't wait to see what happens.
So see you.
There was no code in this video, I think, if I'm right.
But the next videos all throughout this chapter
will be heavily about the code implementation itself.
Oh, also, I already made two whole coding challenges
about steering forces and the flocking system.
So if you wanted to kind of leap ahead,
I'll put links to those as well.
You can go watch those.
Those were made several years ago.
But I'm kind of doubling back now
to go through all this stuff in a bit more detail.
All right.
Thanks for being here.
I hope you like this video.
This was a hard one to do.
And I hope that it made sense.
And let me know what you thought.
I'll see you soon.
Bye.
